results.title: In Mexico, Nearly 100,000 People Are Missing
results.abstract: Nearly 100,000 people have disappeared in Mexico. Their families now search for clues among the dead.

results.title: Jordan’s King Among Leaders Accused of Amassing Secret Property Empire
results.abstract: A leak of nearly 12 million files suggested King Abdullah II was among 35 current and former leaders to use secret shell companies to hide their wealth.

results.title: In a Surge of Military Flights, China Tests and Warns Taiwan
results.abstract: For two straight days, Beijing sent a record number of planes near the island, Taiwan said, a display of strength that underscored Chinese demands for unification.
results.byline: By Chris Buckley and Amy Qin

multimedia.caption: An undated photo from Taiwan’s defense ministry showing a Chinese H-6 bomber. The ministry said H-6 bombers were among the planes that China flew near the island on Friday.

results.title: Skateboards, Climate Change and Freedom: Germany’s Next-Generation Parliament
results.abstract: A new generation of lawmakers is entering Germany’s Parliament. They felt ignored by the previous government, so they set out to change that by winning elections.
results.byline: By Katrin Bennhold and Melissa Eddy

results.title: A Dispatch From an Endangered Bird’s ‘Garden of Eden’
results.abstract: Immerse yourself in the visual splendor of a tiny volcanic island in the northern Andaman Sea, the only home of the little-known Narcondam hornbill.

multimedia.caption: The Narcondam hornbill (Rhyticeros narcondami) is endemic to the tiny island of Narcondam, which is about 160 miles northeast of Port Blair in the Andaman Islands.

results.title: Angelo Codevilla, Whose Writings Anticipated Trumpism, Dies at 78
results.abstract: A hawkish conservative, he believed that America was hamstrung at home and abroad by a progressive ruling class.

multimedia.caption: Angelo Codevilla at the Conservative Political Action Conference in 2013. A leading conservative political theorist, he argued that a liberal elite ruling class was at the heart of much of the nation’s ills.
multimedia.copyright: Gage Skidmore

results.title: They Helped Build Modern India but Are Shrinking as a People
results.abstract: Parsis have supported many of the country’s institutions and nurtured business and the arts. But their numbers have dwindled at an alarming pace.

results.title: 3,000 Yazidis Are Still Missing. Their Families Know Where Some of Them Are.
results.abstract: Seven years after they were captured by the Islamic State, some members of the Iraqi religious minority are still being held captive by fighters in Syria. Others are with families of ISIS militants.

des_facet: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
org_facet: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

results.title: Canadian Man Who Narrated ISIS Videos Flown to U.S. To Face Terrorism Charge
results.abstract: The man, Mohammed Khalifa, was captured in Syria in early 2019. He was part of the Islamic State’s Ministry of Media, which was responsible for publicizing the beheading of the American journalist James Foley.

results.title: Battered Towns in England’s North Test Johnson’s Plan to ‘Level Up’
results.abstract: Prime Minister Boris Johnson has made far-reaching promises to spread the good life beyond prosperous southeastern England to neglected parts in the middle and North of the country.

multimedia.caption: Redevelopment of a former steelworks site in Redcar is part of the government’s plan to “level up” the area.

results.title: Romans Choose From a Crowded Field to Run a Chaotic City
results.abstract: Rome has defied efforts to make basic services work, and the incumbent mayor lags in the polls, with no shortage of rivals hoping to take her place.
results.byline: By Elisabetta Povoledo and Emma Bubola

results.title: U.K. Aims to Ease Trucker Shortage With Visas Into 2022
results.abstract: The decision extended an earlier move to offer three-month visas to foreign drivers, and came as the government also called on military drivers to help resolve a fuel distribution crisis.

results.title: As Bikers Throng the Streets, ‘It’s Like Paris Is in Anarchy’
results.abstract: An ecologically minded experiment to make Paris a cycling capital of Europe has led to a million people now pedaling daily — and to rising tensions with pedestrians.

multimedia.caption: People riding their bikes on the cross of Rue de Rivoli and boulevard Sebastopol — two main bicycles lanes in central Paris during the morning rush hour, in September.

results.title: Perilous, Roadless Jungle Becomes a Path of Desperate Hope
results.abstract: The recent surge at the Mexican border is likely to grow as more migrants, mostly Haitian, risk everything negotiating the notorious Darién Gap on their way to the United States.
results.byline: By Julie Turkewitz, Natalie Kitroeff, Sofía Villamil and Federico Rios

results.title: Stanley Tucci’s Passion Was Acting. Now, It’s Food.
results.abstract: The actor’s new memoir “Taste” explains how a bout with cancer took his passion for ragù and risotto, but also Cuban-Chinese stews and minke whale, to new heights.
des_facet: Stanley Tucci: Searching for Italy (TV Program)

multimedia.caption: “If you can’t eat and enjoy food,” Stanley Tucci said, “how are you going to enjoy everything else?”
